node.title: New HPC MOOSE installation - Error detected in HDF5
node.bodyText:
Our HPC has new OS, so we have install HPC version of MOOSe again. I used following packages
ufrc mkl/2023.2.0 gcc/12.2.0 openmpi/4.1.5 python/3.11 cmake/3.26.4
petsc and libmesh installation was smooth. I got couple of failures with run_tests with  moose test opt step

Hello
the skipped test are normal.
The 2 failures are from a brittle test that is likely pulling in a library you don’t have. Do you mind looking for the actual log of the failed tests in the console output? It should be output while the tests are running.
The hdf5 failures are more serious.
First you need to unload this mkl module. We don’t support intel compilers.
Then it s odd that there is no hdf5 flag in the environment. @cticenhour do we set those during the install?
and you run ‘ldd’ on your executable please? That will tell us which hdf5 you’re running
Guillaume
@GiudGiud I just want to add that I installed moose without mkl module and I am still getting the same error.

@GiudGiud - there is no HDF5 flag set in the environment if the PETSc update and install script is run. In that scenario, HDF5 is built alongside PETSc (using their installation procedure) and then used at the higher levels of the stack automatically. HDF5DIR, etc. is only set when conda is used, and I see conda available, but not used here.
@ykvishal - The suggestion to run ldd on your executable is a good one. It will give us a complete list of the linked libraries, and may shed some light here. If HDF5 exists elsewhere on the machine and different libraries than what PETSc prefers is being used, then you might run into some unexpected behavior. If there was an error in the HDF5 build itself (via the PETSc script), then you may also run into issues, and a clean of the submodule and rebuild of PETSc would be appropriate.

I'm very curious what library is bringing in libhdf5_cpp. I would bet that is the problematic library because as a system library it may clash with the hdf5 libraries being built by petsc.
My hypothesis is that it is netcdf. @roystgnr what do you think?
I changed my mind. hdf5.*cpp only appears in netcdf cmake files for Windows. I don't think it's netcdf. Looking at hdf5.m4 I believe it could be libMesh itself

This is in my own libMesh config.log. We have been bitten by arbitrarily tacking on system paths before and it looks like it is happening again
HDF5_CFLAGS=''
HDF5_CPPFLAGS=''
HDF5_CXXLIBS='-L/lib -lhdf5_cpp -Wl,-rpath,/lib'
HDF5_DIR=''
HDF5_FLIBS='-L/lib -lhdf5_fortran -Wl,-rpath,/lib'
HDF5_LIBS='-L/lib -lhdf5 -Wl,-rpath,/lib'
HDF5_PREFIX=''

That seems like the problem indeed.
We need to build with a consistent HDF5 throughout, and
	libhdf5_cpp.so.103 => /lib64/libhdf5_cpp.so.103 (0x000014a2e2520000)

is not from the same location as the others that Pr Tonks pre-installed

Although I wouldn't necessarily expect us to pick-up /lib64 ... That probably doesn't matter. I'm sure /lib64 is in the default search patch of the linker and so as long as we have -lhdf5_cpp we're doing to pick up the system library.
@ykvishal can you share your config.log which should be in /blue/michael.tonks/v.yadav/MOOSEInstallation/moose/libmesh/build ? So I don't think we need this although it wouldn't hurt to have it
We're doing it at the libMesh level - git logs say @jwpeterson added those flags in libMesh/libmesh#913

I highly doubt we're using the hdf5_cxx API ourselves, but we have a bit of a tradition of detecting things to make it easy for other users to use our ifdefs to avoid having to write detection scripts themselves.

Here is my config.log

HDF5_CPPFLAGS=''
HDF5_CXXLIBS='-L/lib -lhdf5_cpp -Wl,-rpath,/lib'
HDF5_DIR=''
HDF5_FLIBS='-L/lib -lhdf5_fortran -Wl,-rpath,/lib'
HDF5_LIBS='-L/lib -lhdf5 -Wl,-rpath,/lib'
HDF5_PREFIX=''

node.title: Print out the history of iteration number of nonlinear solver
node.bodyText:
Hello Moose community,
Do you know how to print out the number of Newton iteration in nonlinear solver in a final report?
For instance,
at time step 1, the solver is converged after m1 steps,
at time step 2, the solver is converged after m2 steps,
...
at time step n, the solver is converged after mn steps.
And I need to have the information of m1, m2,... and mn in an output report. I wonder how to do it?

use this https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/NumNonlinearIterations.html
it will be available in a CSV file after
It works well. Thank you so much.

node.title: How to set up a updated boundary condition?
node.bodyText:
Hi there,
I want to solve a species transport problem when the flow is a loop, which means there is not a traditional left and right boudnary conditions. Instead, the "boundary" conditions should update at each loop. Does there any case that I can learn from or do you have any idea on how to set up such a boundary conditions?
Thank you very much.
How would you want the conditions to be updated?

I think the best way to do a closed loop is to use a mesh that represents the loop. All the cells are connected naturally.
Then you use a volume region to provide a momentum source, a sort of volumetric pump

I think there are two possible ways to do so:

I have a left and right boundary condition but the boundary conditions should be updated at each time steps. The ith time steps output should be the (i+1)th time steps input. So I need a updated boundary conditions. I am not sure if this is possible in MOOSE setup.
I have a naturally connect mesh loop. In this situation, I will not have a left and right boundary conditions. I only have an initail condition. Here I am not sure if this is going to work without boundary conditions in MOOSE.
Besides, when you said a "momentum source", did you mean an instant input? It only work at the beginning of the running and then dispear. Does it mean "initial condition"?

I have a left and right boundary condition but the boundary conditions should be updated at each time steps. The ith time steps output should be the (i+1)th time steps input. So I need a updated boundary conditions. I am not sure if this is possible in MOOSE setup.

There are various ways to track older states in MOOSE. For instance there is slnOld on the variable classes. There are stateful material properties although those would only work with integrated boundary conditions. You can introduce time dependence through Function objects.

That makes sense. The only thing is I still don't know the expression of the boundary conditions at this time step since it depends on the former time steps. So the input (boundary condition) of this time steps should be the output of former time steps. In this case, it can be physically forming a loop. In this situation, is there any possible way to do so?

To retrieve an old value of a variable, you can use:

coupledValueOld from the coupleable interface (used by most kernels & bcs)
OR
slnOld (different API, directly from the variable class)
OR
the old state arguments, through the FunctorAPI

All of this can work, but I m thinking the big difficulty here is not getting the old state, but matching the two boundaries.
Can you paste an image of your mesh? and highlight the two boundaries you are trying to match

I am on the progress of designing the meshes. I am considering designing a tube mesh and use the right boundary output as the input of  left boundary at nest time step. This means I will have to update the boundary conditions each time. I am not sure if this will work.

node.title: ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress and incremental strain
node.bodyText:
Does MOOSE use hypoelastic (incremental strain) formulation in their ComputeFiniteStrain kernel?


Regarding implementing the ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress kernel, which material model does it use (constitutive model)?


How does the frame of reference (Lagrangian/Eulerian) play a role in the incremental strain approach?


In the tensor mechanics module, is only the static equilibrium equation solved or the full dynamic equation solved?

For the incremental formulation, MOOSE implementation follows this paper " MM Rashid. Incremental kinematics for finite element applications. International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering, 36(23):3937–3956, 1993. "
Most of your questions can be answered by that paper. Here are some short answers:


Does MOOSE use hypoelastic (incremental strain) formulation in their ComputeFiniteStrain kernel?
Yes, incremental for hypoelastic.




Regarding implementing the ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress kernel, which material model does it use (constitutive model)?
HypoElastic.




How does the frame of reference (Lagrangian/Eulerian) play a role in the incremental strain approach?
Eulerian.




In the tensor mechanics module, is only the static equilibrium equation solved or the full dynamic equation solved?
Both, depending on whether the mass and damping terms are included or not.


There is a newer implementation of total formulation. See

Thanks for the reply.
Can you attach the link/documentation here for the implementation of the total formulation?

@MusannaGalib  examples of input files for dynamics problems are here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/tensor_mechanics/Dynamics.html
Basically using DynamicTensorMechanics instead of TensorMechanics
and adding the inertia kernels, you can easily switch from a static
to a dynamic simulation.

node.title: Failed Tests in outputs/ and meshgenerators/ and some warnings during compilation
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Team, I updated my moose repository but when I re-compiled I got a set of warnings, which all seemed to revolve around my use of the M1 Mac. I usually ignore these warnings if all of the tests pass, but this time a handful within outputs/ and meshgenerators/ do fail, all with the error of EXODIFF. The full set of warnings and the details of the EXODIFF errors are too big to copy and pasted, so I attached a couple of .txt files with the entirety of the compilation and test results.
Any advice?
Thanks!
compile_warnings.txt
test_results.txt

The warnings at link time are normal. It's some issue with compilation visibility setttings that get reported by newer compilers.
We all get them. We haven't gotten to fixing that, there's always something more urgent to tackle.
The failures are all tied to Nemesis output
meshgenerators/output_intermediate_mesh.intermediate_mesh_output/nemesis �[90m.......�[0m �[33m[min_cpus=2]�[0m �[33mFAILED (EXODIFF)�[0m
outputs/variables.nemesis_hide �[90m.................................................�[0m �[33m[min_cpus=2]�[0m �[33mFAILED (EXODIFF)�[0m
meshgenerators/distributed_rectilinear/dmg_displaced_mesh.pbc/adaptivity_nemesis �[33m[min_cpus=4]�[0m �[33mFAILED (EXODIFF)�[0m
outputs/nemesis.nemesis_elemental_replicated �[90m...................................�[0m �[33m[min_cpus=4]�[0m �[33mFAILED (EXODIFF)�[0m
outputs/nemesis.nemesis_scalar_replicated �[90m......................................�[0m �[33m[min_cpus=4]�[0m �[33mFAILED (EXODIFF)�[0m

we have JUST done a libmesh submodule update that changes the outcome of these tests. If you update MOOSE without updating libmesh you ll get those failures. If you update libmesh they will go away
Guillaume
I ran 'mamba update --all' but the same tests still fail. Do I need to run something like 'git submodule update --init libmesh' in order to update libmesh? Update: I tried this as well, to no avail.

did you use conda/mamba to install moose?
If so then you should not use the libmesh submodule
btw the mamba update may be failing these days due to dependency resolution issues. See this post:
#25358

Yes I did use mamba to install moose (following the basic Linus/MacOS MOOSE Installation guide).
Do you suggest I perform 'mamba install moose-dev=2023.08.29' for this?
let's do this yes

I made a fresh clone of MOOSE without the libmesh update and tried the old version of moose-dev, but the same five tests still fail.
Any suggestions?

new moose + old libmesh -> expect failure
old moose (pre libmesh update) + new libmesh -> expect failure

node.title: P_hf in HeatTransferFromHeatStructure1Phase
node.bodyText:
Hello. @joshuahansel @GiudGiud
I want to know what the P_hf's effect is. If I define a HeatStructureCylindrical connected with two FlowChannel1Phase. And I define two HeatTransferFromHeatStructure1Phase. When I set the P_hf to 1 in the first HeatTransfer and set the P_hf to 2 in the second. Will the power of the HeatStructureCylindrical be divided into two parts(1/3 and 2/3) for the two FlowChannel1Phase?
I've tried to run a case but it seems the P_hf can't achieve the above things.
Ethan

Hello
From the docs
The parameter ["P_hf"](https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/components/HeatTransferFromHeatStructure1Phase.html#acf4cc4e-ab98-4ab4-8d55-6d003fbee4ff) is optional and specifies the heated perimeter 

if unspecified, this is computed from the cross-sectional area assuming a circular cross section.

so basically the perimeter * the heat transfer coeff * the temperate delta gets you the heat flux.
I think you cant just give an arbitrary value there, you need to get P_hf to be the size it should be for the flux you are trying to get
Guillaume
It seems quite different than I thought. So if I want to build a model: a heat structure connected with two flow channels. How should I set the fraction of the power?

for the fraction of heat flux you mentioned you can set Phf1 = 2 * Phf2 with :

the same heat transfer coefficient for both
the same temperature profiles in both

but the base value of Phf1 / the heat transfer coefficients have to be set to get the heat flux you want. Usually it s just:

Phf1 is the real heated perimeter
Hw is the heat transfer coefficient from a correlation / closure

Can you attach a heat structure to 2 channels btw? I've never done that

Yes, I can. I set two HeatTransferFromHeatStructure1Phase whose hs is the same heat structure and flow_channel is different. But when I set like that, I think the Phf is not working right. When I set the total power and the heat structure, the volumetric heat source is defined. And the Phf*volumetric heat source should be the linear power density using in flow channel.
But I set the model: one hs and one flow channel. And I change the Phf, the rise of the temperature is not changing.
if the Phf is already large enough for all the heat to make its way into the channel, then raising it more will not change much

But I set the model: one hs and one flow channel. And I change the Phf, the rise of the temperature is not changing.

So to be clear, you have issues with just a single HS/flow channel? The rate of heat transfer is proportional to it, with a given HTC and temperature difference. If you're seeing that the temperature distribution over the entire length of the channel is unaltered with the change, then there is definitely something wrong. If you're seeing just that the total temperature rise over the length of the channel is the same, then I'm guessing the channel temperature has approached the temperature of the HS by the time it exits. Which is it?

then I'm guessing the channel temperature has approached the temperature of the HS by the time it exits

I output the steady result.
I check the result again. When I change the Phf, the temperature of flow channel is not changing. But the temperature of the HS is changing. So the heat flux changes indeed. But does this mean that Phf will not affect the amount of energy released into the flow channel? Or maybe I misunderstand sth?
The main question I care is I mentioned above:

So if I want to build a model: a heat structure connected with two flow channels. How should I set the fraction of the power?

When I change the Phf, the temperature of flow channel is not changing. But the temperature of the HS is changing.

When you say the temperature of the flow channel is not changing, do you mean absolutely not changing? Or is the temperature distribution just approximately the same? The statement you've made implied that there is a lack of energy conservation, but that's only if there is absolutely no difference. If the channel is moving fast or has a lot of thermal mass, you made not see much difference.

So if I want to build a model: a heat structure connected with two flow channels. How should I set the fraction of the power?

Your only option with this setup is to do as you have been: you set the different heated perimeters for each channel. I wouldn't expect the split to be exactly 1/3 and 2/3, but I think it should be roughly this.

Phf*volumetric heat source should be the linear power density

This isn't correct. This would give you some number W/m^2.

It‘s approximately the same. OK. Maybe it‘s because the velocity I set is high.
And I forgot the HS length. It should times the length of the HS to get the linear power density.
I ask this question because the temperature of the flow channel is not correct in a 78-channels sodium came. And I will keep testing the question we discuss.

node.title: Nucleation works, but no change in phase field
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose experts,
Hope you are doing great! I am currently simulating random nucleation using phase field approach.
In the nucleation simulation, I am forcing the concentration from 0.2 to 0.9, while the change in the phase field should also occur from 0 to 1 inside the nuclei. I have done this with the help of
      type = DiscreteNucleation
      property_name = Fn
      op_names  = 'c psi'
      op_values = '0.90 1.0'

However, I am seeing a change in the concentration, but no change in the order parameter when nucleation occurs, although, the phase field and concentration are coupled variables in this simulation. Would you be kind to let me what I did wrong? I have attached the file for your convenience here. I would appreciate if you can manage time to reply.
[Mesh]
    type = GeneratedMesh
    dim = 2
    nx = 10
    ny = 10
    xmax = 500
    ymax = 500
    elem_type = QUAD
  []
  
   [Modules]
     [./PhaseField]
       [./Conserved]
         [./c]
           free_energy = F
           mobility = M
           kappa = kappa_c
           solve_type = REVERSE_SPLIT
         [../]
       [../]
      [../]
     [./PhaseField]
       [./Nonconserved]
        [./psi]
          free_energy = F
          mobility = L
          kappa = kappa_c
          coupled_variables = c
        [../]
       [../]
      [../]
    []

  [ICs]
    [./c_IC]
      type = ConstantIC
      variable = c
      value = 0.2
    [../]
    [./psi_IC]
      type = ConstantIC
      variable = psi
      value = 0
    [../]
  []
  
  [Materials]
    [./pfmobility]
      type = GenericConstantMaterial
      prop_names  = 'M L kappa_c'
      prop_values = '1 10 25'
    [../]
    [./chemical_free_energy]
      # simple double well free energy
      type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
      property_name = Fc
      coupled_variables = 'c'
      constant_names       = 'barr_height  cv_eq'
      constant_expressions = '0.1          0'
      expression = 16*barr_height*c^2*(1-c)^2 # +0.01*(c*plog(c,0.005)+(1-c)*plog(1-c,0.005))
      derivative_order = 2
      outputs = exodus
    [../]
    [./probability]
      # This is a made up toy nucleation rate it should be replaced by
      # classical nucleation theory in a real simulation.
      type = ParsedMaterial
      property_name = P
      coupled_variables = c
      expression = 'if(c<0.21,c*1e-8,0)'
      outputs = exodus
    [../]
    [./nucleation]
      # The nucleation material is configured to insert nuclei into the free energy
      # tht force the concentration to go to 0.95, and holds this enforcement for 500
      # time units.
      type = DiscreteNucleation
      property_name = Fn
      op_names  = 'c psi'
      op_values = '0.90 1.0'
      penalty = 5
      penalty_mode = MIN
      map = map
      outputs = exodus
    [../]
    [./free_energy]
      # add the chemical and nucleation free energy contributions together
      type = DerivativeSumMaterial
      derivative_order = 2
      coupled_variables = 'c psi'
      sum_materials = 'Fc Fn'
    [../]
  []
  
  [UserObjects]
    [./inserter]
      # The inserter runs at the end of each time step to add nucleation events
      # that happened during the timestep (if it converged) to the list of nuclei
      type = DiscreteNucleationInserter
      hold_time = 50
      probability = P
      radius = 10
    [../]
    [./map]
      # The map UO runs at the beginning of a timestep and generates a per-element/qp
      # map of nucleus locations. The map is only regenerated if the mesh changed or
      # the list of nuclei was modified.
      # The map converts the nucleation points into finite area objects with a given radius.
      type = DiscreteNucleationMap
      periodic = c
      inserter = inserter
    [../]
  []
  
  [Preconditioning]
    [./SMP]
      type = SMP
      full = true
    [../]
  []
  
  [BCs]
    [./Periodic]

      [../]
    [../]
  []
  
  [Postprocessors]
    [./avg_psi]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = psi
    [../]
    [./dt]
    type = TimestepSize
    [../]
    [./ndof]
      type = NumDOFs
    [../]
    [./rate]
      type = DiscreteNucleationData
      value = RATE
      inserter = inserter
    [../]
    [./dtnuc]
      type = DiscreteNucleationTimeStep
      inserter = inserter
      p2nucleus = 0.0005
      dt_max = 10
    [../]
    [./update]
      type = DiscreteNucleationData
      value = UPDATE
      inserter = inserter
    [../]
    [./count]
      type = DiscreteNucleationData
      value = COUNT
      inserter = inserter
    [../]
  []
  
  [Adaptivity]
    [./Indicators]
      [./jump]
        type = GradientJumpIndicator

    max_h_level = 3
  []

    type = Transient
    scheme = bdf2
    solve_type = 'PJFNK'
    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -sub_pc_type'
    petsc_options_value = 'asm      lu          '
  
    nl_max_its = 100
    l_tol = 1.0e-4
    nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-9
    nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-9
    start_time = 0.0
    num_steps = 200
  
    [./TimeStepper]
      type = IterationAdaptiveDT
      dt = 10
      growth_factor = 1.5
      cutback_factor = 0.5
      optimal_iterations = 8
      iteration_window = 2
      timestep_limiting_postprocessor = dtnuc
    [../]
  []
  
  [Outputs]
    exodus = true
    csv = true
    print_linear_residuals = false
  []
@amjokisaari @laagesen

Hi, thanks for your interest in the MOOSE framework! To answer your question, I think the problem is that you haven't specified any dependence of the free energy F on the order parameter psi.  The Cahn-Hilliard and Allen-Cahn equations are using the free energy F, which is created by the DerivativeSumMaterial (which gives a default property name of F, since you haven't supplied a name for the DerivativeSumMaterial it's going to default to F. For the free energy to have any coupling between c and psi, you would need to add some kind of psi dependence to F. Right now it only depends on c.
Taking a step back from your immediate question, do you need a non-conserved order parameter in this system? If you have a two-phase system that only differs in composition between the phases, you might not need a separate order parameter. That would allow you to use the existing example moose/modules/phase_field/examples/nucleation/cahn_hilliard.i for instance.

Dear Dr. Larry Aagesen,
I appreciate your reply. Your explanation has made my concept clear. Is there any tutorial in MOOSE that explains the way of making free energy dependent on non-conserved order parameter? Any particular expression or mathematical relation! I am also interested in some papers that maybe you would like to suggest me to solve such phase field problems! Best regards, Zahid

Please see the section Multiple Phase Models on our Phase field module documentation page:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/phase_field/index.html#multiple_phase_models

Dear Dr. Larry Aagesen,
Thank you for your kind help. As you suggested, I have made the chemical energy dependent on the non-conserved order parameter (psi).
expression = 16*barr_height*c^2*(1-c)^2*(psi-1)^2

Besides, I have included all the kernels required to solve the terms of Allen-Kahn and Cahn-Hilliard equations. Now, the file is running, However, I am having sever convergence issue with the linear solver.

The linear solver is not converging due to diverged breakdown issue, although the non-linear solver is converging. Would you be kind to help me out identifying the source of this convergence problem!
Though, a direct change in the concentration field due to nucleation is visible, but no change is happening in the non-conserved order parameter. Is there anything missing in the file, even though, concentration (c) and order parameter (psi) are coupled together.

    xmax = 500
    ymax = 500
    elem_type = QUAD
  []
  
   [Modules]
     [./PhaseField]
       [./Conserved]
         [./c]
           free_energy = F
           mobility = M
           kappa = kappa_c
           solve_type = REVERSE_SPLIT
           coupled_variables = psi
         [../]
       [../]
      [../]
     [./PhaseField]
       [./Nonconserved]
        [./psi]
          free_energy = F
          mobility = L
          kappa = kappa_c
          coupled_variables = c
        [../]
       [../]
      [../]
    []

 [Variables]
    [./w]
      order = FIRST
     family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
  []

[Kernels]
    [./c_res]
      type = SplitCHParsed
      variable = c
      f_name = F
      kappa_name = kappa_c
      coupled_variables = psi
      w = w
    [../]
    [./w_res]
      type = SimpleSplitCHWRes
      variable = w
      mob_name = M
    [../]
    [./time]
      type = CoupledTimeDerivative
      variable = w
      v = c
    [../]
    [./detadt]
      type = TimeDerivative
      variable = psi
    [../]
    [./ACBulk]
      type = AllenCahn
      variable = psi
      f_name = F
      coupled_variables = c
    [../]
    [./ACInterface]
      type = ACInterface
      variable = psi
      kappa_name = kappa_c
      variable_L = false
    [../]
    [./initialization_diffusion]
      type = FunctionDiffusion
      variable = psi
      function = '100 * exp(-10 * t)'
    [../]
[]

  [ICs]
    [./c_IC]
      type = ConstantIC
      variable = c
      value = 0.2
    [../]
    [./psi_IC]
      type = ConstantIC
      variable = psi
      value = 0
    [../]
  []
  
  [Materials]
    [./pfmobility]
      type = GenericConstantMaterial
      prop_names  = 'M L kappa_c'
      prop_values = '1 10 25'
    [../]
    [./chemical_energy]
      # simple double well free energy
      type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
      property_name = Fc
      coupled_variables = 'c psi'
      #constant_names       = 'w  cv_eq'
      constant_names       = 'barr_height  cv_eq'
      constant_expressions = '0.1          0'
      #expression = 16*barr_height*c^2*(1-c)^2*psi^2*(psi-1)^2 #+0.01*(c*plog(c,0.005)+(1-c)*plog(1-c,0.005))
      expression = 16*barr_height*c^2*(1-c)^2*(psi-1)^2 #+0.01*(c*plog(c,0.005)+(1-c)*plog(1-c,0.005))
      #expression = 16*barr_height*c^2*(1-c)^2+((psi-1)^2*0.01*(c*log(c)+(1-c)*log(1-c))) #+0.01*(c*plog(c,0.005)+(1-c)*plog(1-c,0.005))
      #expression = 16*w*c^2*(1-c)^2 #+0.01*(c*plog(c,0.005)+(1-c)*plog(1-c,0.005))
      derivative_order = 2
      outputs = exodus
    [../]
    [./probability]
      # This is a made up toy nucleation rate it should be replaced by
      # classical nucleation theory in a real simulation.
      #type = ParsedMaterial
      type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
      property_name = P
      coupled_variables = 'c psi'
      #coupled_variables = 'c'
      expression = 'if(c<0.21,c*1e-8,0)-if(psi<0.5,psi*0.3,0)'
      #expression = 'if(c<0.21,c*1e-8,0)'
      outputs = exodus
    [../]
    [./nucleation]
      # The nucleation material is configured to insert nuclei into the free energy
      # tht force the concentration to go to 0.95, and holds this enforcement for 500
      # time units.
      type = DiscreteNucleation
      property_name = Fn
      op_names  = 'c psi'
      op_values = '0.90 1.0'
      penalty = 5
      penalty_mode = MIN
      map = map
      outputs = exodus
    [../]
    [./free_energy]
      # add the chemical and nucleation free energy contributions together
      type = DerivativeSumMaterial
      derivative_order = 2
      coupled_variables = 'c psi'
      sum_materials = 'Fc Fn'
      property_name = F
    [../]
        # h(eta)
    [./h_eta]
      type = SwitchingFunctionMaterial
      h_order = HIGH
      eta = psi
      function_name = 'h'
    [../]
  
    # g(eta)
    [./g_eta]
      type = BarrierFunctionMaterial
      g_order = SIMPLE
      eta = psi
     function_name = 'g'
    [../]
  []
  
  [UserObjects]
    [./inserter]
      # The inserter runs at the end of each time step to add nucleation events
      # that happened during the timestep (if it converged) to the list of nuclei
      type = DiscreteNucleationInserter
      hold_time = 50
      probability = P
      radius = 10
    [../]
    [./map]
      # The map UO runs at the beginning of a timestep and generates a per-element/qp
      # map of nucleus locations. The map is only regenerated if the mesh changed or
      # the list of nuclei was modified.
      # The map converts the nucleation points into finite area objects with a given radius.
      type = DiscreteNucleationMap
      periodic = c
      inserter = inserter
    [../]
  []
  
  [Preconditioning]
    [./SMP]
      type = SMP
      full = true
    [../]
  []
  
  [BCs]
    [./Periodic]
      [./all]
        auto_direction = 'x y'
      [../]
    [../]
  []
  
  [Postprocessors]
    [./avg_psi]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = psi
    [../]
    [./dt]
    type = TimestepSize
    [../]
    [./ndof]
      type = NumDOFs
    [../]
    [./rate]
      type = DiscreteNucleationData
      value = RATE
      inserter = inserter
    [../]
    [./dtnuc]
      type = DiscreteNucleationTimeStep
      inserter = inserter
      p2nucleus = 0.05
      dt_max = 10
    [../]
    [./update]
      type = DiscreteNucleationData
      value = UPDATE
      inserter = inserter
    [../]
    [./count]
      type = DiscreteNucleationData
      value = COUNT
      inserter = inserter
    [../]
  []
  
  [Adaptivity]
    [./Indicators]
      [./jump]
        type = GradientJumpIndicator
        variable = c
      [../]
    [../]
    [./Markers]
      [./nuc]
        type = DiscreteNucleationMarker
        map = map
      [../]
      [./grad]
        type = ValueThresholdMarker
        variable = jump
        coarsen = 0.1
        refine = 0.2
      [../]
      [./combo]
        type = ComboMarker
        markers = 'nuc grad'
      [../]
    [../]
    marker = combo
    cycles_per_step = 3
    recompute_markers_during_cycles = true
    max_h_level = 3
  []
  
  [Executioner]
    type = Transient
    scheme = bdf2
    solve_type = 'PJFNK'
    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -sub_pc_type'
    petsc_options_value = 'asm      lu          '
    #petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_grmres_restart -sub_ksp_type -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overlap'
    #petsc_options_value = 'asm      31                  preonly       lu           2'
  
    nl_max_its = 100
    l_tol = 1.0e-4
    nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-9
    nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-9
    start_time = 0.0
    end_time = 10000
  
    [./TimeStepper]
      type = IterationAdaptiveDT
      dt = 10
      growth_factor = 1.5
      cutback_factor = 0.5
      optimal_iterations = 8
      iteration_window = 2
      timestep_limiting_postprocessor = dtnuc
    [../]
  []
  
  [Outputs]
    exodus = true
    csv = true
    print_linear_residuals = false
  []

Hello
Please follow the instruction there
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html
and paste a log of a failed simulation here so we can check on what is going wrong.
I m on travel rn, I won't be able to run your case

I see that you've added phi-dependence to the free energy, but I'm not sure what physics you're wanting to implement based on how you've added it. What is the physical system you are trying to simulate? What do the order parameters you're using represent in that system?

Dear Dr. Aagesen,
Thank you for your reply. I am trying to simulate void formation in metals. When the vacancy concentration field reaches from 0.2 to 0.9, the voids start to form. To demarcate the void (supersaturated field) from the vacancy concentration in the matrix, I am using the non-conserved order parameter. Since the free energy is now a function of both vacancy concentration and non-conserved order parameter, I should get a change in the order parameter as well, but it is just not happening. Off course, I have not finalized the free energy formulation looking at the non-conserved order parameter. First, I am trying to bring the file to run in the simplest format. Thanks.

Dear Dr. Larry Aagesen,
I am glad to inform you that I have solved the problem. I actually wanted to identify the nucleation of voids with a jump in non-conserved order parameter, though it can be captured by using the concentration jump alone.
Thanks.

node.title: About Mesh
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE experts,
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  nx = 14
  ny = 14
  xmax = 9
  ymax = 9
  uniform_refine = 3
[]

I don't understand what "uniform_refine = 3" means.  What is the effect on mesh establishment? What is the difference between uniform_refine = 3 and uniform_refine = 2?
Thank you.

If you have nx = 14, ny = 14 means you have 14 elements along the x direction and 14 elements along the y direction.
Uniform refine = 1 will make nx = 28, ny = 28
Uniform refine = 2 will make nx = 56, ny = 56
Uniform refine = 3 will make nx = 128, ny = 128
This happens at the mesh setup step.
This changes in 3D when the refinement also has another dimension to do
I understand. Thank you very much
I think that it should be  Uniform refine = 3 will make nx = 112, ny = 112 instead of  Uniform refine = 3 will make nx = 128, ny = 128 , The uniform refine = n option changes mesh by nx * 2^n

node.title: restart with TensorMechanics (reloading stress state without interpolating)
node.bodyText:
Hi,
We are running a simulation based on a (THM) moose application, which includes the tensor mechanics module.
E.g., we have the following block in our input file:
[Modules]
  [./TensorMechanics]
    [./Master]
      [./all]
      add_variables = true
      strain = SMALL
      incremental = true
      eigenstrain_names = 'reduced_eigenstrain'
      volumetric_locking_correction = true
      additional_generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_xy stress_xz stress_yy stress_yz stress_zz'
      [../]
    [../]
  [../]
[]

When we reach some critical state in the simulation, we want to extract the stresses from Moose, use them in another code, update the stresses and restart a new moose simulation. Let's forget about the update of the stress, but focus on the loading of the previous stress state in a new moose simulation. We are currently doing it using a SolutionUserObject reading the exodus output file from the first simulation.
[UserObjects]
  [./solution_loop]   
    type = SolutionUserObject
    mesh = output.e      # should be the name of output in first loop
    timestep = LATEST
  [../]
[]
[Functions]
  [sxx_functionT]
    type = SolutionFunction
    from_variable = 'stress_xx'
    solution = 'solution_loop'
    execute_on = 'INITIAL'    
 []

And we use sxx_functionT to initialize the new simulation. But this does not work perfectly. The new stress differs slightly (interpolation) from the last time step of the first simulation.
Our mesh is 3D unstructured with lower dimensional elements (2D fault, and 1D wells).
We think it does not work perfectly because probably the SolutionUserObject interpolate stress_xx from the volume element
onto the 2D fault, instead of loading the 2D data from the exodus file.
Therefore, it would be better to load the stress from the exodus file using checkpointing rather than  SolutionUserObject (e.g. using initial_from_file_timestep = xx). But how can we do that, given that the variables stress_ij are not defined anywhere in our input file, except in the TensorMechanics block copied above?
Thanks in advance for your help,
Thomas Ulrich.

Hello
To use checkpoint you ll want the system to be exactly the same size before and after the restart.
If that is so, you can set "restart_file_base" in the Problem block, and it will restart everything it can.
You can also use a SolutionUO with a checkpoint file, but I think it will always interpolate
Guillaume
thank you I will try

Hello
Yeah the install takes forever on WSL, and so does running the tests.
You would not have run out of memory running the tests. So you could have ./run_tests -j8 for example
You just dont get as much performance on WSL. We recommend using either a computing cluster or a strong laptop running linux or macos natively
